trans-unit.source: Validates an X.509 certificate.
Use the <xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509CertificateValidator> class to specify how an X.509 certificate is deemed valid.

This can be done using by deriving a class from <xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509CertificateValidator> and overriding the <xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509CertificateValidator.Validate%2A> method.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509CertificateValidator"></xref> class.
By default, this constructor doesn't initialize any properties.
Gets a validator that validates the X.509 certificate using a trust chain.
This validator verifies that the X.509 certificate is valid and issued by a trusted issuer using a certificate chain.
The value of this static property can be supplied as a parameter to one of the constructors for the <xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509SecurityTokenAuthenticator> class.
A <xref href="System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509CertificateValidator"></xref> that validates the X.509 certificate using a trust chain.
Gets a validator that verifies the X.509 certificate by specifying the context and chain policy that is used to build and verify a trust chain.

Use the <xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509CertificateValidator.CreateChainTrustValidator%2A> method instead of the <xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509CertificateValidator.ChainTrust%2A> property to specify the context or to set chain policy.
Chain policy can be used to specify the Enhanced Key Usage (EKU) for which the chain should be validated, or specify revocation checking.
The return value for this static method can be supplied as a parameter to the constructors for the <xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509SecurityTokenAuthenticator> class that take a validator.
`true` to use the machine context; `false` to use the current user context.
An <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainPolicy"></xref> that specifies the policy used to build and verify the trust chain.
A <xref href="System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509CertificateValidator"></xref> that validates the X.509 certificate using a trust chain.
Gets a validator that verifies the certificate is in the `TrustedPeople` certificate store or by specifying the context and chain policy that is used to build a certificate trust chain.
The certificate is trusted if it passes either verification method.

Use the <xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509CertificateValidator.CreatePeerOrChainTrustValidator%2A> method instead of the <xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509CertificateValidator.PeerOrChainTrust%2A> property to specify the context or to set chain policy.
Chain policy can be used to specify the Enhanced Key Usage (EKU) for which the chain should be validated, or specify revocation checking.
The value of this static property can be supplied as a parameter to one of the constructors for the <xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509SecurityTokenAuthenticator> class.
`true` to use the machine context; `false` to use the current user context.
An <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainPolicy"></xref> that specifies the policy used to build the trust chain.
A <xref href="System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509CertificateValidator"></xref> that verifies the certificate is in the `TrustedPeople` certificate store or by building a certificate trust chain.
When overridden in a derived class, loads custom configuration from XML.
By default, throws a <xref:System.NotImplementedException>.
You can override this method to provide functionality in a derived class.
The custom configuration elements.
Gets a validator that performs no validation on an X.509 certificate.
As a result, an X.509 certificate is always considered to be valid.
This validator can be useful when working with a test or development X.509 certificate, such as one generated by the Makecert.exe utility.
The value of this static property can be supplied as a parameter to one of the constructors for the <xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509SecurityTokenAuthenticator> class.
A <xref href="System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509CertificateValidator"></xref> that performs no validation on the X.509 certificate.
Gets a validator that verifies the certificate is in the `TrustedPeople` certificate store or by building a certificate trust chain.
The certificate is trusted if it passes either verification method.
The value of this static property can be supplied as a parameter to one of the constructors for the <xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509SecurityTokenAuthenticator> class.
A <xref href="System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509CertificateValidator"></xref> that verifies the certificate is in the `TrustedPeople` certificate store or by building a certificate trust chain.

A <xref href="System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509CertificateValidator"></xref> that verifies the certificate is in the `TrustedPeople` certificate store.
When overridden in a derived class, validates the X.509 certificate.
Override the <xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.X509CertificateValidator.Validate%2A> method to specify how the X.509 certificate is validated.
When the X.509 certificate that is passed into the `certificate` parameter does not pass validation, throw the <xref:System.IdentityModel.Tokens.SecurityTokenvalidationException>.
The <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate2"></xref> that represents the X.509 certificate to validate.
